{{more citations needed|date=October 2016}} [[File:Carved Conch.jpg|thumb|Carved conches or Vamavarta shankhas, ''circa'' 11-12th century, [[Pala Empire|Pala period]], India: The leftmost one is carved with the image of [[Lakshmi]] and [[Vishnu]], and has silver additions.]] [[File:Shankha with rosette.jpg|thumb|A Shankha (conch shell) with Vishnu emblem carved.]] A '''Shankha''' is a [[conch]] [[Gastropod shell|shell]] of ritual and religious importance in [[Hinduism]] and [[Buddhism]]. It is the shell of a large predatory sea snail, ''[[Turbinella pyrum]]'', found in the [[Indian Ocean]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} In [[Hindu mythology]], the shankha is a sacred [[emblem]] of the Hindu preserver god [[Vishnu]]. It is still used as a [[trumpet]] in Hindu ritual, and in the past was used as a war trumpet. The shankha is praised in Hindu scriptures as a giver of fame, longevity and prosperity, the cleanser of sin and the abode of goddess [[Lakshmi]], who is the goddess of wealth and consort of [[Vishnu]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} The shankha is displayed in [[Hindu art]] in association with Vishnu. As a symbol of water, it is associated with female fertility and serpents ([[NƒÅga]]s). The shankha is the state emblem of the Indian state of [[Seal of Kerala|Kerala]] and was also the national emblems of the Indian [[princely state]] of [[Travancore]], and the [[Kingdom of Cochin]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} The shankha is one of the eight auspicious symbols of [[Buddhism]], the [[Ashtamangala]], and represents the pervasive sound of Buddhism.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} A powder made from the shell material is used in [[ayurveda]] as a treatment for stomach ailments.{{Cite news|url=https://www.ayurtimes.com/shankh-shankha-bhasma/|title=Shankh (Shankha) Bhasma|access-date=2016-12-29}} In the [[Western world]], in the [[English language]], the shell of this species is known as the "divine conch" or the "sacred chank". It may also be simply called a "chank" or conch. The more common form of this shell is known as "left-turning" in a religious context, although scientists would call it "dextral". A very rarely encountered form has reverse coiling which is called "right-turning" in a religious context, but is known as "sinistral" or left-coiling in a scientific context.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} ==Characteristics== This [[gastropod shell|shell]] is from a [[sea snail]] species ''[[Turbinella pyrum]]'' in the family [[Turbinellidae]]. This species is found living in the Indian Ocean and surrounding seas. The shell is porcelaneous (i.e. the surface of the shell is strong, hard, shiny, and somewhat translucent, like [[porcelain]]).{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} The overall shape of the main body of the shell is oblong or conical. In the oblong form, it has a protuberance in the middle, but tapers at each end. The upper portion (the [[Siphon (mollusc)|siphonal canal]]) is corkscrew-shaped, while the lower end (the [[Spire (mollusc)|spire]]) is twisted and tapering. Its colour is dull, and the surface is hard, brittle and translucent. Like all snail shells, the interior is hollow. The inner surfaces of the shell are very shiny, but the outer surface exhibits high tuberculation.{{Cite book|last= Nadkarni |first= K. M. |title= Dr. K. M. Nadkarni's Indian Materia medica|work=Turbinella Rapa; or Xanchus Pyrum or Gastropoda, Class: Molusca|pages=164‚Äì165|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s0GJ5NJymywC&pg=PA165&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=YmwcS_LVKozSkwTXh8nxCw#v=onepage&q=Shankha&f=false|publisher= Popular Prakashan |year=1994|isbn=81-7154-143-7}} In Hinduism, the shiny, white, soft shankha with pointed ends and heavy is the most sought after. ===Types=== Based on its direction of coiling, the shankha has two varieties:{{Cite book|last= Mookerji |first= Bhudeb |title= The wealth of Indian alchemy & its medicinal uses: being an...|volume = 1| work=Shankh| page=195| accessdate=2009-12-21| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aWxGAAAAYAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=c20cS4eCMYGQkATM4PycDA|publisher= Sri Satguru|year=1998|isbn=81-7030-580-2}}{{Cite book|last= Thottam |first= Dr. P.J. |title= Modernising Ayurveda|work=Shankh|pages=38‚Äì39|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JdsQSIX5WH8C&pg=PA38&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=emkcS6F6obKQBLGBmYcM#v=onepage&q=Shankha&f=false |publisher= Sura Books |year=2005|isbn=81-7478-640-6}} ====Significance of the ''Dakshinavarta shankha''==== *A [[Dakshinavarti Shankh]]: This is the very rare sinistral form of the species, where the shell coils or whorls expand in a counterclockwise spiral if viewed from the apex of the shell. *The ''Vamavarta'' ("left-turned" as viewed with the aperture uppermost): This is the very commonly occurring dextral form of the species, where the shell coils or whorls expand in a clockwise spiral when viewed from the apex of the shell. In Hinduism, a ''dakshinavarta shankha'' symbolizes infinite space and is associated with Vishnu. The ''Vamavarta shankha'' represents the reversal of the laws of nature and is linked with [[Shiva]].Jansen p. 43 The ''Dakshinavarta shankha'' is believed to be the abode of the wealth goddess [[Lakshmi]] - the consort of Vishnu, and hence this type of shankha is considered ideal for medicinal use. It is a very rare variety from the [[Indian Ocean]]. This type of shankha has three to seven ridges visible on the edge of the [[aperture (mollusc)|aperture]] and on the [[columella (mollusc)|columella]] and has a special internal structure. The right spiral of this type reflects the motion of the planets. It is also compared with the hair whorls on [[the Buddha]]'s head that spiral to the right. The long white curl between Buddha's eyebrows and the conch-like swirl of his navel are also akin to this shankha.{{Cite web|url=http://www.navaratna-museum.info/Shells.html|title=Sri Navaratna Museum of Natural Wonders|accessdate=2009-12-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091206204802/http://navaratna-museum.info/Shells.html|archivedate=2009-12-06|df=}} The ''[[Varaha Purana]]'' tells that bathing with the ''Dakshinavarta shankha'' frees one from sin. [[Skanda Purana]] narrates that bathing Vishnu with this shankha grants freedom from sins of seven previous lives. A ''Dakshinavarta shankha ''is considered to be a rare "jewel" or ''ratna'' and is adorned with great virtues. It is also believed to grant longevity, fame and wealth proportional to its shine, whiteness and largeness. Even if such a shankha has a defect, mounting it in gold is believed to restore the virtues of the shankha. ==Uses== [[File:Hindu priest blowing conch during punja.jpg|thumb|right|Hindu priest blowing a shankha during a [[Puja (Hinduism)|''puja'']]]] In its earliest references, shankha is mentioned as a [[trumpet]] and in this form it became an emblem of Vishnu. Simultaneously, it was used as a votive offering and as a charm to keep away the dangers of the sea. It was the earliest known sound-producing agency as manifestation of sound, and the other elements came later, hence it is regarded as the original of the elements. It is identified with the elements themselves.{{Cite book|last= Krishna |first= Nanditha|title= The art and iconography of Vishnu-Narayana|work=Shankh|pages=31, 36 and 39|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ahrqAAAAMAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=emkcS6F6obKQBLGBmYcM|publisher= D.B. Taraporevala|year=1980}} {{Cite book|last= Nayak |first= B. U. |author2=N. C. Ghosh |author3=Shikaripur Ranganatha Rao |title= New Trends in Indian Art and Archaeology| work=Shankha| pages=512‚Äì513| accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IsCFAAAAIAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=7G4cS4yINJWQlQTWqM2FDA|publisher= Aditya Prakashan|year=1992|isbn=81-85689-12-1}} To make a trumpet or wind instrument, one drills a hole near the tip of the [[apex (mollusc)|apex]] of the shankha. When air is blown through this hole, it travels through the whorls of the shankha, producing a loud, sharp, shrill sound. This sound is the reason the shankha was used as a war trumpet, to summon helpers and friends. Shanka continued to be used in battles for a long time. The sound it produced was called ''shankanad''.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Nowadays, the shankha is blown at the time of worship in Hindu temples and homes, especially in the ritual of the Hindu ''[[aarti]]'', when light is offered to the deities. The shankha is also used to bathe images of deities, especially Vishnu, and for ritual purification. No hole is drilled for these purposes, though the aperture is cut clean or rarely the whorls are cut to represent five consecutive shells with five mouths.{{cite book|last=Rajendralala Mitra|title=Indo-aryans|series=285-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V8KoGspmBGgC&pg=PA287&dq=sankha&lr=&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=44#v=onepage&q=sankha&f=false | isbn=978-1-4067-2769-2 | year=2006 | publisher=Read Books}}{{Cite book|last= Avtar |first= Ram |title= Musical instruments of India: history and development|work=Shankh|pages=41, 42|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lL3oAAAAIAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=c20cS4eCMYGQkATM4PycDA|publisher= Pankaj Publications |year=1983}} Shankha is used as a material for making bangles, bracelets and other objects. Because of its aquatic origin and resemblance to the [[vulva]], it has become an integral part of the [[Tantra|Tantric]] rites. In view of this, its symbolism is also said to represent female fertility. Since water itself is a fertility symbol, shankha, which is an aquatic product, is recognised as symbolic of female fertility. In ancient [[Greece]], shells, along with [[pearl]]s, are mentioned as denoting sexual love and marriage, and also mother goddesses. Different magic and sorcery items are also closely connected with this trumpet. This type of device existed long before the [[Buddha|Buddhist]] era.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}}

2- Some people also say that the conch floral flower gives flowering flowers within 5‚Äì10 minutes, which is also found in this flower carbohydrate and this chemical reacts in the inner part of this flower , And the gas flows out, causing the flower to bloom immediately. ===Ayurveda=== Shankha is used in [[Ayurveda]] medicinal formulations to treat many ailments. It is prepared as conch shell ash, known in Sanskrit as ''shankha [[bhasma]]'', which is prepared by soaking the shell in lime juice and calcinating in covered crucibles, 10 to 12 times, and finally reducing it to powder ash. Shankha bhasma contains calcium, iron and magnesium and is considered to possess antacid and digestive properties.{{cite book|last=Lakshmi Chandra Mishra|title=Scientific basis for Ayurvedic therapies |page=96|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qo0VPGr0RF4C&pg=PT120&dq=sankha&lr=&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=57#v=onepage&q=sankha&f=false | isbn=978-0-8493-1366-0 | year=2004 | publisher=CRC Press}} A compound pill called ''shankavati'' is also prepared for use in [[dyspepsia]]. In this case, the procedure followed is to mix ''shankha bhasma'' with [[tamarind]] seed ash, five salts ([[panchlavana]]), [[asafoetida]], [[ammonium chloride]], [[black pepper|pepper]], [[carui]], [[caraway]], [[ginger]], [[long pepper]], purified [[mercury (element)|mercury]] and [[aconitine|aconite]] in specified proportions. It is then triturated in juices of lemon and made into a pill-mass. It is prescribed for ''vata'' (wind/air) and ''pitta'' (bile) ailments, as well as for beauty and strength. ==Significance== [[File:Travancore State Flag.png|thumb|A sacred shankha on the flag of [[Travancore]], [[India]]]] The sound of the shankha symbolises the sacred ''[[Om]]'' sound. Vishnu holding the conch represents him as the god of sound. [[Brahma Vaivarta Purana]] declares that shankha is the residence of both Lakshmi and Vishnu, bathing by the waters led through a shankha is considered as like bathing with all holy waters at once. [[Sankha Sadma Purana]] declares that bathing an image of Vishnu with cow milk is as virtuous as performing a million ''[[yajna]]s'' (fire sacrifices), and bathing Vishnu with [[Ganges]] river water frees one from the cycle of births. It further says "while the mere sight of the conch (shankha) dispels all sins as the Sun dispels the fog, why talk of its worship?"{{cite book|last=Aiyar V.AK|title=Symbolism In Hinduism|pages=283‚Äì6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kMqD8YrB23QC&pg=PA283&dq=sankha&lr=&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=37#v=onepage&q=sankha&f=false | isbn=978-81-7597-149-3 | publisher=Chinmaya Mission}} [[Padma Purana]] asserts the same effect of bathing Vishnu by Ganges water and milk and further adds doing so avoids evil, pouring water from a shankha on one's own head before a Vishnu image is equivalent to bathing in the pious Ganges river. In [[Buddhism]], the conch shell has been incorporated as one of the eight auspicious symbols, also called ''[[Ashtamangala]]''. The right-turning white conch shell ({{bo|t=‡Ωë‡Ω¥‡ΩÑ‡ºã‡ΩÇ‡æ±‡Ω¶‡ºã‡Ω†‡ΩÅ‡æ±‡Ω≤‡Ω£|w=dung gyas 'khyil}}), represents the elegant, deep, melodious, interpenetrating and pervasive sound of Buddhism, which awakens disciples from the deep slumber of ignorance and urges them to accomplish their own welfare and the welfare of others.{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} Shankha was the Royal State Emblem of [[Travancore]] and also figured on the Royal Flag of the [[Jaffna kingdom]]. It is also the election symbol of the Indian political party [[Biju Janata Dal]].{{citation needed|date=October 2016}} ==In Hindu iconography and art== [[File:Conque (Mus√©e des arts asiatiques, Nice) (5941349262).jpg|thumb|left|A shankha carved]] Shankha is one of the main attributes of Vishnu. Vishnu's images, either in sitting or standing posture, show him holding the shankha usually in his left upper hand, while ''[[Sudarshana Chakra]]'' (''chakra'' - discus), [[Kaumodaki|''gada'']] (mace) and ''[[padma]]'' (lotus flower) decorate his upper right, the lower left and lower right hands, respectively.{{Cite web|url=http://www.religiousportal.com/SacredShankha.html|title=Sacred Shankha (Conch Shell)|accessdate=2009-12-21|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702120045/http://www.religiousportal.com/SacredShankha.html|archivedate=2007-07-02|df=}} [[File:Dattatreya temple Bhaktapur Nepal.jpg|thumb|The ''shankha'' on the right is the icon for Vishnu at the Dattatreya temple, Bhaktapur Nepal]] [[Avatar]]s of Vishnu like [[Matsya]], [[Kurma]], [[Varaha]] and [[Narasimha]] are also depicted holding the shankha, along with the other attributes of Vishnu. [[Krishna]] - avatar of Vishnu is described possessing a shankha called [[Panchajanya]]. Regional Vishnu forms like [[Jagannath]] and [[Vithoba]] may be also pictured holding the shankha. Besides Vishnu, other deities are also pictured holding the shankha. These include the sun god [[Surya]], [[Indra]] - the king of heaven and god of rainJansen pp. 66-7 the war god [[Kartikeya]],Jansen p. 126 the goddess [[Matrikas|Vaishnavi]]Jansen p. 131 and the warrior goddess [[Durga]].{{cite book|last=Helle Bundgaard, Nordic Institute of Asian Studies|title=Indian art worlds in contention|pages=183, 58|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=royx-12WRiwC&pg=PA58&dq=sankha&lr=&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=24#v=onepage&q=sankha&f=false | isbn=978-0-7007-0986-1 | year=1999 | publisher=Routledge}} Similarly, [[Ashta Lakshmi|Gaja Lakshmi]] statues show [[Lakshmi]] holding a shankha in the right hand and lotus on the other.{{Cite book|last= Srivastava |first= R. P.|title= Studies in Panjab sculpture |work=Shank|pages=40‚Äì42|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bHm6nKenVK4C&pg=PT146&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=V2ccS9K-IIf4lQSb04ngDg#v=onepage&q=Shankha&f=false|publisher =Lulu.com |isbn=0-9793051-1-X}} Sometimes, the shankha of Vishnu is personified as ''[[Ayudhapurusha]]'' "weapon-man" in the sculpture and depicted as a man standing beside Vishnu or his avatars.Rao, p. 156 This subordinate figure is called the Shankhapurusha who is depicted holding a shankha in both the hands. Temple pillars, walls, [[gopuram|gopuras]] (towers), basements and elsewhere in the temple, sculpted depictions of the shankha and chakra - the emblems of Vishnu - are seen.{{Cite book|last= Dallapiccola |first= Anna Libera |author2=Anila Verghese |title= Sculpture at Vijayanagara: iconography and style|work=Shankh|pages=44, 58|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9GzqAAAAMAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=U3QcS9HbKJTmlATTmqDaCw |publisher= Manohar Publishers & Distributors for [[American Institute of Indian Studies]].|year=1998|isbn=81-7304-232-2}} The city of [[Puri]] also known as [[Samkha Kshetra|Shankha-kshetra]] is sometimes pictured as a shankha or conch in art with the [[Jagannath]] temple at its centre. [[Shaligram]]s are iconographic [[fossil]] stones particularly found in the [[Gandaki River]] in Nepal which are worshipped by Hindus as representative of Vishnu. The shaligrama - which has the marks of a shanka, chakra, gada and padma arranged in this particular order ‚Äì is worshipped as [[Keshava]]. Twenty-four orders of the four symbols defined for Shaligrama are also followed in worship of images of Vishnu with different names. Out of these, besides Keshava the four names of images worshipped starting with Shankha on the upper hand, are: [[Madhusudanah]], [[Damodar (name of Krishna)|Damodara]], [[Balarama]] and [[Vamana]].{{Cite book|last= Debroy|first= Bibek|author2=Dipavali Debroy |title= The Garuda Purana| work=Shalagrama| page=42| accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bHm6nKenVK4C&pg=PT146&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=V2ccS9K-IIf4lQSb04ngDg#v=onepage&q=Shankha&f=false|isbn=0-9793051-1-X | publisher=Lulu.com}}Rao pp.231-232 ==In Hindu legend== A Hindu legend in the ''[[Brahma Vaivarta Purana]]'' recalls the creation of conchs: [[Shiva]] flung a trident towards the [[asura]]s, burning them instantaneously. Their ashes flew in the sea creating conchs. Shankha is believed to be a brother of Lakshmi as both of them were born from the sea. A legend describes an asura named Shankhasura, who was killed by Vishnu's fish [[avatar]], [[Matsya]].{{cite book|last=B. A. Gupte|title=Hindu holidays and ceremonials|page=xx|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_FSWKWzNSagC&pg=PR20&dq=matsya+demon+Vishnu+conch&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=8#v=onepage&q=matsya%20demon%20Vishnu%20conch&f=false | isbn=978-81-206-0953-2 | year=1994 | publisher=Asian Educational Services}} [[File:Shankha bajaudai.jpg|thumb|A sadhu sounding the ''shankha''.]] In the [[Hindu epic]]s of [[Ramayana]] and [[Mahabharata]], the symbol of Shankha is widely adopted. In the Ramayana epic, [[Lakshmana]], [[Bharata (Ramayana)|Bharata]] and [[Shatrughna]] are considered as part-incarnations of [[Sheshanaga]], [[Sudarshana Chakra]] and Shankha, respectively, while [[Rama]], their eldest brother, is considered as one of the ten [[Avatar]]s of shri Vishnu.{{Cite book|last= Naidu |first= S. Shankar Raju|author2=Kampar, Tulasƒ´dƒÅsa |title= A comparative study of Kamba Ramayanam and Tulasi Ramayan| work=Shank| pages=44,148| accessdate=2009-12-21| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=okVXAAAAMAAJ&q=Shankha&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=emkcS6F6obKQBLGBmYcM|publisher= University of Madras|year=1971}} During the great Mahabharata war, Krishna, as the charioteer of the [[Pandava]] prince and a protagonist of the epic - [[Arjuna]] - resounds the Panchajanya to declare war. Panchajanya in Sanskrit means 'having control over the five classes of beings'. All five Pandava brothers are described having their own shankhas. [[Yudhishthira]], [[Bhima]], Arjuna, [[Nakula]] and [[Sahadeva]] are described to possess shankhas named Ananta-Vijaya, Poundra-Khadga, Devadatta, Sughosha and Mani-pushpaka, respectively. ==Association with NƒÅgas== Because of the association of the shankha with water, [[nƒÅga]]s are often named after the shankha. The list of NƒÅgas in the ''[[Mahabharata]]'', the ''[[Harivamsha]]'' and the ''[[Bhagavat Purana]]'' includes names like Shankha, Mahashankha, Shankhapala and Shankachuda. The last two are also mentioned in the Buddhist [[Jataka Tales]] and the ''[[Jimutavahana]]''.{{cite book|title=Indian Serpent Lore Or the Nagas in Hindu Legend and Art |pages=215‚Äì16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nU8JRyvXWnYC&pg=PA215&dq=sankha&lr=&as_brr=3&client=firefox-a&cd=16#v=onepage&q=sankha&f=true | first=J. | last=Vogel | isbn=978-0-7661-9240-9 | year=2005 | publisher=Kessinger Publishing}} A legend states that while using Shankha as part of meditative ritual, a [[sadhu]] blew his shankha in the forest of village Keoli and a snake crept out of it. The snake directed the sadhu that he should be worshipped as NƒÅga Devata (Serpent God) and since then it has been known as Shanku Naga. Similar legends are narrated at many other places in [[Kullu district]] in [[Himachal Pradesh]].{{Cite book|last= Handa |first= Omacanda |title= Naga cults and traditions in the western Himalaya|work=Shankh|page=200|accessdate=2009-12-21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xd50t19YpJEC&pg=PA200&dq=Shankha&lr=&ei=U3QcS9HbKJTmlATTmqDaCw#v=onepage&q=Shankha&f=false |publisher= Indus Publishing |year=2004|isbn=81-7387-161-2}} ==See also== * [[Melo melo]] * [[Dakshinavarti Shankh]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== *Anthology of World Music: The Music of Tibetan Buddhism. [Booklet notes by Peter Crossley-Holland.] [CD] Massachusetts: Rounder Select *Ellingson, T. (1979). The Mandala of Sound: Concepts and Sound Structures in Tibetan Ritual Music. Ann Arbor, Michigan: UMI * {{cite book|last=Hornell|first=James|title=The sacred Chank of India: A monograph of the Indian Conch (Turbinella pyrum) - Online Book|authorlink=James Hornell|publisher=The Superintendent, Government Press, Madras|year=1914|isbn=|page=|url=https://archive.org/stream/sacredchankofind00horn#page/n5/mode/2up|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723113020/http://www.archive.org/stream/sacredchankofind00horn#page/n5/mode/2up|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2012-07-23|df=}} *{{cite book|last=Jansen|first=Eva Rudy|title=The Book of Hindu Imagery: Gods, Manifestations and Their Meaning|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1iASyoae8cMC&pg=PA144|year=1993|publisher=Binkey Kok Publications|location=Diever|isbn=978-90-74597-07-4|pages=144‚Äì}} *Kumar, N (2004). [[Religious studies]] | published = 2005 ([[Wisdom Publications]]) | media_type = [[Paperback]] | pages = 224 | isbn = 0-86171-497-0 | dewey= 294.3/367914375 22 | congress= BQ5405 .B67 2005 | oclc= 57211202 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The Dharma of Star Wars''''' is a book by [[Matthew Bortolin]]. The book is a primer for basic [[Buddhist]] philosophy using the fictional characters and events of the [[Star Wars]] saga to explicate the Buddha's teachings. Bortolin, an ordained Zen Buddhist and Star Wars fan, explains the principles and practices of Buddhism through the words and actions of [[Darth Vader]], [[Luke Skywalker]], [[Yoda]] and other Star Wars characters. The book also examines the underlying philosophical ideas of Star Wars from a Buddhist perspective. ==External links== * http://www.filmthreat.com/index.php?section=interviews&Id=948 {{DEFAULTSORT:Dharma of Star Wars, The}} [[Category:2005 books]] [[Category:American non-fiction books]] [[Category:Buddhism studies books]] [[Category:Non-fiction books about Star Wars]] {{StarWars-stub}} {{Buddhism-book-stub}}

Fr. '''Theodore Jurewicz''' ({{lang-ru|–§–µ–æ–¥–æ—Ä –Æ—Ä–µ–≤–∏—á}}; born 1953, [[Erie, Pennsylvania]]) is a [[Polish-American]] Orthodox [[edinoverie|old-rite]] priest and artist specializing in painting [[Byzantine]] [[icon]]s and [[fresco]]es. Father Jurewicz is also an archpriest of the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]], and serves the parish of the Nativity of the Lord in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Michael |last=Woerl |url=http://www.orthodoxinfo.com/ecumenism/bookrev_woerl.aspx |title=Book Review: A History of the Orthodox Church in America (1917-1934) |publisher=Orthodox Christian Information Centre |accessdate=26 December 2009 |quote=Father Theodore Jurewicz is a priest of the Russian Orthodox Church Abroad, serving the parish of the Nativity of the Lord in Erie, Pennsylvania.}}</ref>
==Art== Fr. Theodore was born Frank Jurewicz in 1949 into a [[Roman Catholic]] family in [[Erie, Pennsylvania]].
As a child he attended church assiduously and often visited the Old Believer parish of the Nativity of Christ in Erie. From these visits he developed a deep interest in the [[Orthodox Church]], and, while still a teenager, converted to Orthodoxy and joined the [[Russian Orthodox Church Outside Russia]].
He married and attended the [[Holy Trinity Orthodox Seminary|Holy Trinity Seminary]] as a married seminarian.
In January 1974, Theodore Jurewicz was ordained priest.
Fr. Jurewicz is held to be one of the most renowned icon painters in [[North America]] today,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.stgeorgehermitage.org/frescoes.html |title=As of June 2009, our Fresco Fund is currently at $18,163.80 |publisher=St George Serbian Orthodox Church (Hermitage, PA) |accessdate=26 December 2009 |quote=We are very fortunate to have as our neighbor, the world-renowned iconographer, Fr. Theodore Jurewicz, archpriest to the Church of the Nativity Russian Orthodox Church in Erie. Only one hour away is one of the greatest Orthodox painters of our time!}}</ref> and has painted about a dozen [[Eastern Orthodox church architecture|Eastern Orthodox churches]] across [[North America]]. He was a student of the late Archimandrite Cyprian, founder of the Russian school of iconography outside of Russia.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.holy-transfiguration.org/ourchurch.html |title=Our Iconostasis |publisher=Transfiguration of Our Lord Russian Orthodox Church (Baltimore, USA) |accessdate=26 December 2009 |quote=Father Theodore Jurewicz was the student of the late Archimandrite Cyprian, founder of the Russian school of iconography outside of Russia. From his teacher Father Theodore acquired the ancient Russian style of iconography, which adorns the iconostasis of the church of Transfiguration.}}</ref>
One of his more famous works was his commission to paint the entire church at [[New Graƒçanica Monastery]] in [[Third Lake, Illinois]], a faithful replica of the original [[Graƒçanica monastery]] in [[Kosovo]], which is listed on the [[UNESCO World Heritage List]] as an endangered example of medieval monuments. Done over the span of three years, it is painted in a [[Byzantine]] style and features richly colored designs and religious scenes covering the [[wall]]s, [[vault (architecture)|vaults]], [[Column|pillars]] and [[dome]] of the church. The [[fresco]]es are painted in [[Acrylic paint|acrylics]] on dry [[plaster]].<ref name="Gracanica">{{cite web |url=http://www.newgracanica.com |title=New Gracanica Monastery: The Frescoes |publisher=New Gracanica Monastery (Third Lake, IL) |accessdate=26 December 2009 |quote=In 1995, the fresco project began. Fr. Theodore Jurewicz was commissioned to paint the entire church. The project took three years. Fr. Theodore, one of the most profound and celebrated iconographers in America today, came in stretches of three weeks to a month to do the work. The style is Byzantine and the richly colored designs and religious scenes that cover the walls, vaults, pillars and dome of the church are imbued with bright colors. ... The frescoes painted by Fr. Theodore and other contemporary iconographers are done in acrylics on dry plaster.}}</ref>
Another notable commission of Fr. Theodore is the [[Saint Sava Serbian Orthodox Church (Merrillville, Indiana)|Saint Sava Serbian Orthodox Church in Merrillville, Indiana]] where he painted the original frescoes lining the walls and a fresco of the Virgin Mary and the Christ child over the center altar.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nwitimes.com/uncategorized/new-st-sava-serbian-church-a-work-of/article_9a13de2b-9259-5bfa-9666-bc696ac4fcfe.html|title=New St. Sava Serbian church a 'work of love'|last=Calderone Jostes|first=Diane|website=nwitimes.com|access-date=2016-03-17}}</ref>
Fr. Theodore has also mastered the art of [[Coptic art#Iconography|Coptic Orthodox iconography]]. His Coptic iconography can be seen at St. George Coptic Orthodox Church in [[Toledo, Ohio]].<ref>http://www.stgeorgetoledo.com/Home.html</ref>

{{SpecialChars | image = Standard Tibetan name.svg | special = [[Standard Tibetan|Tibetan script]] | fix = Help:Multilingual support (Indic) | characters = [[Tibetan script|Tibetan characters]] | error = [[mojibake|question marks, boxes, or other symbols]] }} The '''Third Bardor Tulku Rinpoche''' ({{bo|t=‡Ω†‡Ωñ‡Ω¢‡ºã‡Ω¢‡æ°‡Ωº‡Ω¢‡ºã‡Ω¶‡æ§‡æ≤‡Ω¥‡Ω£‡ºã‡Ω¶‡æê‡Ω¥‡ºç|w='bar-rdor sprul-sku}}) is a [[Tibetan Buddhist]] teacher, a holder of the religious [[Lineage (Buddhism)|lineage]] of Terchen Barway Dorje. [[Rinpoche]] is the founder of a Tibetan Buddhist center, Kunzang Palchen Ling,{{cite web|url=http://www.kunzang.org|title=HOME - Kunzang Palchen Ling - Tibetan Buddhist Center|work=Kunzang Palchen Ling|accessdate=30 March 2015}} and the Raktrul Foundation,{{cite web|url=http://www.raktrul.org|title=The Raktrul Foundation is an all volunteer charity benefiting people in remote areas of Tibet.|work=raktrul.org|accessdate=30 March 2015}} in [[Red Hook, New York]]. {{Infobox person |name = The Third Bardor Tulku Rinpoche |image = BTR-byRobertHansenSturm-web.jpg |alt = Bardor Tulku Rinpoche |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|05|01}} |birth_place = [[Kham]], East Tibet |death_date = |death_place = |other_names = |known_for = |occupation = Buddhist teacher |nationality = [[Tibetan people|Tibetan]] }} == Biography == Born in 1949 in [[Kham]], East Tibet, the Third Bardor Tulku Rinpoche is believed, according to Tibetan Buddhist tradition, to be a rebirth of a nineteenth/twentieth century meditation master, Terchen Barway Dorje (1836-1920).{{Citation | last = Gyamtso | first = Yeshe | title = Precious Essence. The Inner Autobiography of Terchen Barway Dorje | publication-date = 2005 | publisher = [[KTD Publications]] | page = | isbn = 0-9741092-5-8 }}{{Citation | last = Gyamtso | first = Yeshe | title = Treasury of Eloquence. The songs of Barway Dorje | publication-date = 2007 | publisher = [[KTD Publications]] | page = | isbn = 978-1-934608-00-5 }} {{cite web|url=http://www.snowlionpub.com/pages/N67_17.html|title=Tibetan / Vajrayana|work=Shambhala Publications|accessdate=30 March 2015}}{{Citation | last = Urgyen | first = Tulku | title = Blazing Splendor | publication-date = 2007 | publisher = [[Rangjung Yeshe Publications]] | page = | isbn = 978-962-7341-56-7 }}, [http://www.rangjung.com/blazingsplendor/blazing-glossary.htm Glossary] After the failed [[1959 Tibetan uprising]], Rinpoche and his family left Tibet for [[India]]. The journey on foot over the [[Himalayas]] and later the tropical climate of [[Assam]] killed Rinpoche's family. Rinpoche eventually traveled to [[Darjeeling]] where [[Rangjung Rigpe Dorje|the 16th Karmapa]] (1924-1981) found him and arranged for him to be taken to [[Rumtek Monastery]] in [[Sikkim]].More detailed description of the Third Bardor Tulku Rinpoche's escape from Tibet can be found on the [http://www.kunzang.org/btr-biography.html Kunzang Palchen Ling] web site. The Third Bardor Tulku Rinpoche is mentioned among the prominent [[lama]]s of the [[Kagyu]] tradition of Tibetan Buddhism.[https://www.nytimes.com/2000/02/18/nyregion/finding-karma-through-youth-woodstock-s-tibetan-monastery-prepares-for-a-lama.html'' Finding Karma Through Youth; Woodstock's Tibetan Monastery Prepares for a Lama''], [[New York Times]], February 2000{{cite web|url=http://www.snowlionpub.com/pages/N57_12.html|title=Tibetan / Vajrayana|work=Shambhala Publications|accessdate=30 March 2015}}[http://www.sptimes.com/2004/01/11/Northoftampa/A_visit_from_the__pre.shtml ''Bardor Tulku, a Buddhist spiritual leader, visits Tampa's Buddhist community''], [[St. Petersburg Times]], January 2004 He underwent his training as a ''[[tulku]]'' (reincarnate lama) under the tutelage of the 16th Karmapa at Rumtek Monastery. He remained close to the Karmapa throughout his life, serving as his attendant and traveling with him overseas. At his request, he stayed in the United States to help [[Khenpo Karthar Rinpoche]] and Mr. Tenzin Chonyi establish the Karmapa‚Äôs Seat in North America, [[Karma Triyana Dharmachakra]].{{Citation | last = Drodul | first = Karma | title = Amrita of Eloquence. A Biography of Khenpo Karthar Rinpoche | publication-date = 2009 | publisher = [[KTD Publications]] | page = | isbn = 978-1-934608-05-0 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.snowlionpub.com/pages/N57_4.html|title=Tibetan / Vajrayana|work=Shambhala Publications|accessdate=30 March 2015}} Rinpoche started teaching in the West in 1980s. He has taught at KTD and its affiliates,[http://www.albanyktc.org/pdf/BTR_09-07-08.pdf Karma Thegsum Choling Albany] (NY), [http://www.kagyu.org/kagyulineage/centers/usa/usa-ann.php Karma Thegsum Choling Ann Arbor] (MI), [http://www.abqktc.org/btr09.pdf Karma Thegsum Choling Albuquerque] (NM), [http://www.kagyu.org/kagyulineage/centers/usa/usa-ari.php Karma Thegsum Choling Arizona] (AZ), [http://www.ktcboston.org/g2/main.php?g2_itemId=21 Karma Thegsum Choling Boston] (MA), [http://www.chicagoktc.org/teachings.shtml Karma Thegsum Choling Chicago] (IL), [http://www.columbusktc.org/fly/BTROctober2008.pdf Karma Thegsum Choling Columbus] (OH), [http://www.ktcdallas.org/news/pdfs/fall2006.pdf Karma Thegsum Choling Dallas] (TX), '''Tiddy Mun''' was a legendary [[bog]] [[spirit]] in [[Lincolnshire]], [[England]], who was believed to have the ability to control the waters and mists of [[The Fens]] of South Lincolnshire and The Carrs of North Lincolnshire.
==Legend== The belief in Tiddy Mun was first documented in June 1891 in an article by M. C. Balfour in [[the Folklore Society]] journal ''Folk-Lore''. In the article she recalls a story, collected in the [[River Ancholme|Ancholme Valley]], told to her by an older person who spoke of a [[curse]] of pestilence that had been cast upon his village by the Tiddy Mun, who was angered at the [[The Fens#Early modern attempts to drain the Fens|draining of the Fens]] by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]], led by [[Cornelius Vermuyden]], in the seventeenth century. According to the story the Tiddy Mun was eventually placated after the villagers gathered at twilight at the time of the new moon, poured buckets of water into the dyke and apologised for the damage caused.
He was not exclusively malevolent; if the Fens flooded and the waters reached the villages, people would go out at night and call ''Tiddy Mun wi'out a name, tha watters thruff!'' ("Tiddy Mun without a name, the water's through!<ref>Peacock, E (1889) A Glossary of Words used in the Wapentakes of Manley and Corringham, Lincolnshire. English Dialect Society: Trubner page 562</ref>") until they heard the cry of a [[Northern lapwing|peewit]], and the next morning the waters would have receded.<ref name="Balfour">{{cite journal|title=Legends Of The Cars|journal=Folk-Lore|date=June 1891|first=M. C. |last=Balfour|volume=2|issue=2|pages=145‚Äì170|jstor=1253522|publisher=Folklore Enterprises, Ltd.|doi=10.1080/0015587x.1891.9720054}}</ref>
In his 1987 ''[[The Folklore Society#Publications|Folklore]]'' paper "Tiddy Mun's Curse and the Ecological Consequences of Land Reclamation", Darwin Horn argues that all but one of Tiddy Mun's specific curses may be connected to misfortune and disease brought about by the effect of draining the fenland.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Tiddy Mun's Curse and the Ecological Consequences of Land Reclamation |journal=Folklore|year=1987 |last=Horn |first=Darwin |volume=98 |issue=1 |pages=11‚Äì15 |jstor=1259396 |doi=10.1080/0015587x.1987.9716391}}</ref>
==Description== The Tiddy Mun was described, by folklorist M.C. Balfour in 1891, as being no bigger than a three-year-old child, but looking like an old man with long, tangled white hair and a matted white beard. He is said to have worn a grey gown so that at dusk he was difficult to see. His laughter was said to resemble the call of the peewit.<ref name="Balfour" />
==The Tiddy people== Writing in 1955, folklorist E. H. Rudkin also records another Ancholme Valley belief of an imp-like race of beings who were generally considered mischievous but benevolent. They were 'called the Tiddy people', but also ''the Strangers'', ''Greencoaties'' and ''Yarthin''. The 'Tiddy' name related to their size and Rudkin quotes a source describing them: 'They be tiddy critturs, no more than a span high, wi' arms an' legs as thin as thread, but great big feet an' hands, an' heads rollin' aboot on their shoulders'.<ref name="Rudkin">{{cite journal |title=Folklore of Lincolnshire: Especially the Low-Lying Areas of Lindsey |journal=Folklore |year=1955 |last=Rudkin |first=E.H. |volume=66 |issue=4 |pages=393‚Äì395 |jstor=1258804 }}</ref>
The Tiddy people would dance, by moonlight, on large flat stones, known as ''Strangers Stones'', found in the area. Rudkin records a local tradition of smearing the stones with blood and lighting fires on them, but was unable to determine a meaning, or specific belief, behind the practice.<ref name="Rudkin"/> The first of the crops would also be left on the ''Strangers Stones'', as well as bread and salt, to keep the Tiddy people happy and ensure a good harvest.<ref name="Rudkin"/>
==References in popular culture== * In ''Caliban and the Fen Demons of Lincolnshire: The Englishness of Shakespeare's Tempest'', Dr Todd Andrew Borlik identifies Tiddy Mun as a possible inspiration for [[Caliban]] in [[William Shakespeare|William Shakespeare's]] ''[[The Tempest]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Caliban and the Fen Demons of Lincolnshire: The Englishness of Shakespeare's Tempest |journal=Shakespeare: Journal of the British Shakespeare Association |year=2013 |last=Borlik |first=Todd |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=21‚Äì51 |url=https://www.academia.edu/3287415/Caliban_and_the_fen_demons_of_Lincolnshire_the_Englishness_of_Shakespeares_Tempest |accessdate=2014-12-14 |doi=10.1080/17450918.2012.705882}}{{failed verification|date=December 2017}}</ref>
